post_text: Welcome back to school!
shared_text:
SMORE.COM
Cullman City Schools
text:
Welcome back to school!

SMORE.COM
Cullman City Schools

post_text:
ATTENTION! Families and students of the Cullman City School System

We are so excited that the USDA has approved for us to serve ALL STUDENTS FOR FREE STARTING TOMORROW!!!🎉

That means each and every student!

Paid and reduced students will also all be FREE for BREAKFAST AND LUNCH!! This will be in effect until December 31 or until USDA says otherwise.

VERY IMPORTANT! Please continue to fill out the household application for free and reduced form as we need those for our schools to continue to receive their federal funds. As of now, your child will go to their regular approved status in January, so this form is still very important.

Be sure to join us for breakfast and lunch for the rest of the semester at no charge!
*A la carte items will still be available for purchase as well.*

post_text: Remember that training for NEW substitute teachers will be today at 5:00 at CHS! It has been moved to Tillman Hall. Please enter through the front of the school. (If you are currently on our approved sub list you do not have to attend. Information for you will be coming soon.)

post_text:
Parents,
Some of you accessed the CCS app and found schedules for your students. Please know that those schedules are NOT correct. Once parents have indicated their selection for school setting, those rosters will all have to be readjusted to balance class sizes so that they are as small as they can possibly be. This means your child will likely have different classes and/or pods when their final schedule is available. When all schedules are complete, we will notify all parents of login info so that you can see your child’s actual schedule.
We appreciate your patience while we work to arrange the safest possible setting for your student.

Remember to complete the Parent Choice of School setting form available at https://www.cullmancats.net/site/default.aspx?DomainID=1585

post_text:
The Cullman City Schools will begin the 2020-21 school year on August 19, 2020 pending guidelines set forth by the Alabama State Department of Education. We are excited to begin the new school year though we will have many challenges ahead of us. Our primary goal is to provide a safe and instructionally sound plan for reopening the Cullman City Schools. We are providing parents two options for their child to receive the best education possible. The Traditional option allows students to return to the school campus and receive face to face instruction, although the school day will look different than in the past. The Tradition option includes a remote opportunity transitioning from campus to online work at home as needed following guidance from the ADPH and CDC to ensure a safe learning environment. The Virtual option allows students to work from home through the Schoology learning platform. Attendance is tracked daily requiring students to log in daily to complete assignments. Grades will be given to determine promotion/retention (same as with Traditional option). With the Virtual option, instruction is directed by a virtual teacher not the classroom teacher.

We all must work together to help ensure safety by following guidance from the ADPH and CDC.
We ask that parents:
check your children’s temperatures and do not send them to school if 100.4 or greater.
Monitor your children for symptoms daily, including cough, congestion, shortness of breath, or gastrointestinal symptoms. Any positives should be kept home from school.
Our attendance policy will be revised and shared at a later date.

The CCS Central Office has sent out parent surveys via email to determine which educational option parents feel is best for their child. Parents are asked to register for one option by July 17, 2020. You will need to complete a separate form for each student in your family. This form can be accessed at https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSemX-yuiL-SB8xMs_riyJxIjDm4UfWqCmE0yAUKzM7HIYa-cg/viewform?usp=sf_link

We want all of our parents to know how much we appreciate thier patience as we navigate our new school year.

Dr. Susan Patterson
Superintendent

post_text:
Memorandum
Date: March 26, 2020
To: Cullman City Schools
From: Dr. Susan Patterson
Re: School Closure due to COVID-19

Governor Kay Ivey and State Superintendent Dr. Eric Mackey announced that students will not be returning to traditional school during the 2019-20 school year in an effort to protect our students, staff and all Alabamians as we continue to fight the spread of COVID-19. Cullman City Schools is well prepared to transition our student learning and we are actively engaged in the development of a plan that will ensure the continued success of our students.
We will be receiving additional guidance from the Alabama State Department of Education and will wait until we have that guidance to complete our plan. Our primary focus will be to ensure that students have the necessary resources to effectively move their learning forward. This will include, but not be limited to, quality meals through our child nutrition program, access to learning devices and programs, and distance learning options.
It is critical that we all do our part in adhering to the social distancing and other guidelines being emphasized by the CDC and ADPH to help stop the spread of COVID-19. Please be on the lookout for more communication via our school system’s mobile app, phone call system, and social media platforms.

Sincerely,
Susan Patterson, Ed.D Superintendent

post_text: Cullman City Schools will be in session Monday, March 16, 2020, to include extended day services. Students will be excused if they do not attend. Students will be allowed to pick up any materials or supplies they may need from school on Monday. Cullman City Schools will be closed beginning Tuesday, March 17th and will tentatively re-open April 6th, 2020.
text: Cullman City Schools will be in session Monday, March 16, 2020, to include extended day services. Students will be excused if they do not attend. Students will be allowed to pick up any materials or supplies they may need from school on Monday. Cullman City Schools will be closed beginning Tuesday, March 17th and will tentatively re-open April 6th, 2020.

shared_text:
VOX.COM
Vox - Understand the News

Robin D. Mackey
March 14 at 4:03 PM ·

Good morning Facebook Friends! The Mackey household is working at full-speed this morning with questions coming from lots of folks. I am helping to get information out and respectfully request that you share this across your networks. For the folks who get this as a share, Eric Mackey, my husband, is State Superintendent of Education.

As you can imagine, there are basically three groups of people reaching out to both Eric and myself:

1) People who are scared that the schools aren't closing until Wednesday afternoon. We can understand why folks are concerned.

2) People who are upset that schools are closing at all. We can understand why folks are concerned.

3) People who are desperately trying to figure out how to help. These folks make my heart sing.

To address situation 1: All school absences in Alabama public K-12 schools will be excused Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday. Parents and caregivers should make the decision that is best for their family. AL.Com posted the excused absence information earlier today.

To address situation 2: School closings are a serious hardship for parents. It's a great thing that the Federal Government is working to ensure that folks who miss work will get paid. I don't know how this will work or what the limits of this are, but there is an article on VOX.com that provides details on the bill that has come out of the House and will considered by the Senate on Monday. Whether they have paid time off or not, many parents and caregivers need time to make child care plans. Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday provide a time "cushion" to help families plan.

Additionally, many children will go hungry during school closings. The extra time allows for local schools and communities to make plans to feed children during the closure period. There is a Federal Waiver which will allow school feeding programs to continue during the closure. The waiver applies to school in high poverty areas and for students who are eligible for free and reduced lunch.

There has not yet been a waiver for after school and community based organization feeding programs. We will keep you posted on this.

To address situation 3: Schools, communities, churches and individuals are rushing to the front lines to make sure children are taken care of. For instance, one school we know of has the gym open this morning for people to bring food to be packed and sent home with students next week.

This is a local community challenge and, for coordinating purposes, each community is different. You know the folks in your community to connect with to make sure children's needs are met. If you want to help, reach out to those folks. Having been a social worker for 27 years, I want to remind you to expect some chaos as your local efforts come together to help students. Some communities have a natural connection that people will automatically know to reach out to while other communities will not and plans will have to be made and implemented.

Eric says wash your hands, stay 6 feet away from everyone and stay well!

Eric says wash your hands, stay 6 feet away from everyone and stay well!

VOX.COM
Vox - Understand the News

post_text: Please support the Cullman City Schools Foundation, which has consistently provided recognition for our teachers of the year as well as annual funding through classroom grants. Cullman City Schools is fortunate to have the support and partnership of CCSF.
shared_text:
Cullman City Schools
September 9, 2019 at 8:31 PM ·

The Cullman City Schools' Foundation luncheon is Friday, September 20th.
Come have lunch with us, and your ticket purchase will help support classroom teachers through grants for educational projects.
The honorees this year include Cullman City Schools Teachers of the Year, Allison Bates (CCPS), Kelly Thrasher (EES), Salena Mayberry (WES), Kylie Bates (CMS), and John Drake (CHS), as well as Promising Alumnus, Jacob Calahan, and Distinguished Alumna Dr. Rhonda Quick whose award will be accepted by her sister Regina.
Tickets may be purchased through the central office at 256-734-2233 or from Susan Boyd at Cullman High School at sboyd@cullmancats.net.

post_text:
Two years ago, Cullman City Schools launched an app to help parents stay informed of student grades, attendance, lunch balance, and school news. Today, parents who have never logged into the app received an email about how to login to the app. If you did not receive an email, one of two things has happened. 1- you have logged into the app before OR 2- the email address associated with your parent account is invalid.
If you need assistance logging into the app, please email help@cullmancats.net and someone will get with you soon.

iTunes https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/cullman-bearcats/id1291541749?mt=8&ign-mpt=uo%3D4

Google Play https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.blackboard.community.cullmancats&hl=en

Mobile Web App https://cullmancats.parentlink.net/m

Click here to support IMAX Movie on McWane Center Field Trip! organized by ANNA HOWELL ANDERSON

LeanStream
November 20, 2018 at 8:35 PM ·

Way to go Cullman City Schools! Thanks to your community's generosity, the IMAX movie project is FULLY FUNDED so now all 72 1st graders at Cullman City Primary School will get to see an IMAX movie at the McWane Center. The screen is huge and these first graders will be amazed for sure. So congrats!

And don't forget that there are lots of other great ways to help your kids on Cullman City's site (http://bit.ly/SupportCCS). The cool thing is that it doesn't take a huge donation to make a difference - every dollar truly counts. So find a "need" that inspires you and think abut giving a few extra bucks today.. The kids will win and you will feel good too!
